Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Lawn signs sprouting everywhere. Round-the-clock ads on radio and television. The phone rings. It's a robo-call from the president, or his opponent, asking for your money, and your vote. And while you're at it, watch their YouTube videos and like them on Facebook. Election time. We all know the look and feel of modern campaigns. But what was it like in the early days of the Republic, when, say, George Washington ran for office? Well, in fact, he didn't run. When Washington became the first president in 1789, there were no political parties, no conventions or primaries, no campaign, no election season. Not really any candidates. Even the year was odd. Literally. 1789 was the only presidential election ever held in an odd year. After the framers invented the constitution and the presidency 225 years ago, the country set about the business of choosing its first executive. Agreeing with Ben Franklin, many people thought "The first man at the helm will be a good one," and by that, Franklin meant George Washington. Greatest hero of the Revolution, Washington presided over the convention that created the constitution, rarely speaking. He never discussed the job of president, or of wanting it. And when the first presidential election took place, it was a crazy-quilt affair, with many hands stitching the pattern. Under the new constitution, each state was given a number of electors. who would cast a vote for two names. The man with the most votes would be president, the second-place finisher was vice president. Ah, but who picked the electors? That was left up to the states. Six of them let the people decide, or at least white men over 21 who owned property. In New Jersey, some women voted, a right later taken away. But in other states, the legislature picked the electors. At that time, many people thought democracy was one step away from mob rule and a decision this important should be left to wiser men. These electors then voted for president. All the states had to do was get their votes in on time. But there were glitches. Only 10 of the 13 states voted. Rhode Island and North Carolina hadn't ratified the constitution and couldn't vote. New York missed the deadline for naming its electors, and also was not counted. When the votes were tallied, it was unanimous. George Washington won easily. John Adams trailed far behind, finishing second, and became the vice president. Told of his victory, George Washington was not surprised. At Mount Vernon, his bags were already packed. He moved to New York City, the nation's temporary capital, and he would have to figure out just what a president was supposed to do. Since that first election, American democracy and elections have come a long way. The constitution has been changed to open up voting to more people: black men, women, Native Americans, and eighteen-year-olds included. Getting that basic right extended to all those people has been a long, hard struggle. So when you think you can't stand any more of those lawn signs, and TV ads, just remember: the right to vote wasn't always for everyone, and that's a piece of history worth knowing.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Under the original plan for electing the president, the vice president was:
Options: A. The second-place voter getter, B. Chosen by the new president, C. Chosen by the Senate, D. Selected by lottery
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. The first presidential election was held in 1789., B. The first presidential election was held in an even years., C. George Washington presided over the convention that created the constitution., D. The first presidential election was held in the state of New York. Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. The first presidential election was a competitive and contested process., B. The first presidential election was a unanimous decision., C. George Washington was surprised by his victory in the first presidential election., D. The first presidential election was held in the nation's permanent capital. Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. In a modern presidential election, each state has a number of electors who cast a vote for two names., B. In a modern presidential election, the man with the most votes becomes the president and the second-place finisher becomes the vice president., C. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a national popular vote., D. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a vote of the electoral college. Correct Option: D
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The first presidential election was a result of a democratic process where the people directly elected the president., B. The first presidential election was a result of a democratic process where the people indirectly elected the president through electors., C. The first presidential election was a result of a monarchical process where the king appointed the president., D. The first presidential election was a result of a military coup where the general appointed the president. Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. The first presidential election was a result of a combination of democratic and monarchical processes., B. The first presidential election was a result of a combination of democratic and military processes., C. The first presidential election was a result of a combination of monarchical and military processes., D. The first presidential election was a result of a purely democratic process. Correct Option: A
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. The first presidential election was a fair and just process that reflected the will of the people., B. The first presidential election was an unfair and unjust process that did not reflect the will of the people., C. The first presidential election was a neutral process that did not reflect the will of the people., D. The first presidential election was a complex process that had both fair and unfair elements. Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. George Washington was the only president to be unanimously elected., B. George Washington was the first president to be elected by a national popular vote., C. George Washington was the first president to be elected by the electoral college., D. George Washington was the first president to be elected in an odd year. Correct Option: D
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. The first presidential election was held in a country with a well-established democratic tradition., B. The first presidential election was held in a country with a relatively new democratic tradition., C. The first presidential election was held in a country with a monarchical system of government., D. The first presidential election was held in a country with a military dictatorship. Correct Option: B
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a vote of the people., B. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a vote of the electoral college., C. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a combination of popular vote and electoral college vote., D. In a modern presidential election, the president is elected by a national popular vote. Correct Option: C
Question 10: **Analysis** Options: A. The first presidential election was a result of a democratic process where the people directly elected the president through a national popular vote., B. The first presidential election was a result of a democratic process where the people indirectly elected the president through electors., C. The first presidential election was a result of a monarchical process where the king appointed the president., D. The first presidential election was a result of a military coup where the general appointed the president. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The first presidential election was a result of a democratic process where the people indirectly elected the president through electors., C. The first presidential election was a result of a monarchical process where the king appointed the president., D. The first presidential election was a result of a military coup where the general appointed the president.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Lawn signs sprouting everywhere. Round-the-clock ads on radio and television. The phone rings. It's a robo-call from the president, or his opponent, asking for your money, and your vote. And while you're at it, watch their YouTube videos and like them on Facebook. Election time. We all know the look and feel of modern campaigns. But what was it like in the early days of the Republic, when, say, George Washington ran for office? Well, in fact, he didn't run. When Washington became the first president in 1789, there were no political parties, no conventions or primaries, no campaign, no election season. Not really any candidates. Even the year was odd. Literally. 1789 was the only presidential election ever held in an odd year. After the framers invented the constitution and the presidency 225 years ago, the country set about the business of choosing its first executive. Agreeing with Ben Franklin, many people thought "The first man at the helm will be a good one," and by that, Franklin meant George Washington. Greatest hero of the Revolution, Washington presided over the convention that created the constitution, rarely speaking. He never discussed the job of president, or of wanting it. And when the first presidential election took place, it was a crazy-quilt affair, with many hands stitching the pattern. Under the new constitution, each state was given a number of electors. who would cast a vote for two names. The man with the most votes would be president, the second-place finisher was vice president. Ah, but who picked the electors? That was left up to the states. Six of them let the people decide, or at least white men over 21 who owned property. In New Jersey, some women voted, a right later taken away. But in other states, the legislature picked the electors. At that time, many people thought democracy was one step away from mob rule and a decision this important should be left to wiser men. These electors then voted for president. All the states had to do was get their votes in on time. But there were glitches. Only 10 of the 13 states voted. Rhode Island and North Carolina hadn't ratified the constitution and couldn't vote. New York missed the deadline for naming its electors, and also was not counted. When the votes were tallied, it was unanimous. George Washington won easily. John Adams trailed far behind, finishing second, and became the vice president. Told of his victory, George Washington was not surprised. At Mount Vernon, his bags were already packed. He moved to New York City, the nation's temporary capital, and he would have to figure out just what a president was supposed to do. Since that first election, American democracy and elections have come a long way. The constitution has been changed to open up voting to more people: black men, women, Native Americans, and eighteen-year-olds included. Getting that basic right extended to all those people has been a long, hard struggle. So when you think you can't stand any more of those lawn signs, and TV ads, just remember: the right to vote wasn't always for everyone, and that's a piece of history worth knowing.

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Translator: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Most people have heard of the Electoral College during presidential election years. But what exactly is the Electoral College? Simply said, it is a group of people appointed by each state who formally elect the President and Vice President of the United States. To understand how this process began and how it continues today, we can look at the Constitution of the United States: article two, section one, clause two of the constitution. It specifies how many electors each state is entitled to have. Since 1964, there have been 538 electors in each presidential election. How do they decide on the number 538? Well, the number of electors is equal to the total voting membership of the United States Congress. 435 representatives, plus 100 senators, and 3 electors from the District of Columbia. Essentially, the Democratic candidate and Republican candidate are each trying to add up the electors in every state so that they surpass 270 electoral votes, or just over half the 538 votes, and win the presidency. So how do states even get electoral votes? Each state receives a particular number of electors based on population size. The census is conducted every 10 years, so every time the census happens, states might gain or lose a few electoral votes. Let's say you're a voter in California, a state with 55 electoral votes. If your candidate wins in California, they get all 55 of the state's electoral votes. If your candidate loses, they get none. This is why many presidential candidates want to win states like Texas, Florida, and New York. If you currently add up the electoral votes of those three states, you would have 96 electoral votes. Even if a candidate won North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, Wyoming, Vermont, New Hampshire. Connecticut and West Virginia, they would only gain 31 electoral votes total from those eight states. Here is where it can get a little tricky. On a rare occasion, like in the year 2000, someone can win the popular vote but fail to gain 270 electoral votes. This means that the winner may have won and collected their electoral votes by small margins, winning just enough states with just enough electoral votes, but the losing candidate may have captured large voter margins in the remaining states. If this is the case, the very large margins secured by the losing candidate in the other states would add up to over 50% of the ballots cast nationally. Therefore, the losing candidate may have gained more than 50% of the ballots cast by voters, but failed to gain 270 of the electoral votes. Some critics of the electoral college argue the system gives an unfair advantage to states with large numbers of electoral votes. Think of it this way. It is possible for a candidate to not get a single person's vote -- not one vote -- in 39 states, or the District of Columbia, yet be elected president by winning the popular vote in just 11 of these 12 states: California, New York, Texas, Florida, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, New Jersey, North Carolina, Georgia or Virginia. This is why both parties pay attention to these states. However, others argue that the electoral college protects small states such as Rhode Island, Vermont and New Hampshire, and even geographically large states with small populations like Alaska, Wyoming and the Dakotas. That's because a candidate can't completely ignore small states, because in a close election, every electoral vote counts. There are certain states that have a long history of voting for a particular party. These are known as "safe states." For the past four election cycles -- in 1996, 2000, 2004 and 2008 -- Democrats could count on states like Oregon, Maryland, Michigan and Massachusetts, whereas the Republicans could count on states like Mississippi, Alabama, Kansas and Idaho. States that are teetering between between parties are called "swing states." In the past four election cycles, Ohio and Florida have been swing states, twice providing electoral votes for a Democratic candidate, and twice providing electoral votes for a Republican candidate. Think about it. Do you live in a safe state? If so, is it a Democratic or Republican safe state? Do you live in a swing state? Are your neighboring states swing or safe? Is the population in your state increasing or decreasing? And do not forget, when you are watching the electoral returns on election night every four years and the big map of the United States is on the screen, know that the magic number is 270 and start adding.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the electoral college?
Options: A. A university founded to help aspiring politicians with their campaigns, B. A group of academics that report to the government during election season, C. A group of people appointed by each state who formally elect the president and vice president, D. A government entity founded by the signers of the Declaration of Independence that ensures a fair election
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. The Electoral College is a group of people elected by each state to formally elect the President and Vice President of the United States., B. The Electoral College is a group of people appointed by the President to advise on legislation., C. The Electoral College is a system used to determine the winner of a presidential election., D. The Electoral College is a group of people elected by the people to represent their state in Congress. Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the total voting membership of the United States Congress., B. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the total population of the United States., C. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the number of states in the United States., D. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the number of representatives in the House of Representatives. Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 55 electoral votes, they will receive 55 electoral votes from that state., B. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 10 electoral votes, they will receive 10 electoral votes from that state., C. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 5 electoral votes, they will receive 5 electoral votes from that state., D. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 20 electoral votes, they will receive 20 electoral votes from that state. Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The Electoral College system gives an unfair advantage to states with large numbers of electoral votes., B. The Electoral College system gives an unfair advantage to states with small numbers of electoral votes., C. The Electoral College system is fair and gives equal representation to all states., D. The Electoral College system is biased towards urban areas. Correct Option: A
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 11 states, while losing the popular vote in the remaining 39 states., B. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in all 50 states., C. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 5 states., D. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 2 states. Correct Option: A
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. The Electoral College system is a good way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., B. The Electoral College system is a bad way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., C. The Electoral College system is a neutral way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., D. The Electoral College system is not relevant to small states. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question has the most similar intent, options, and content to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions ask about the definition of the Electoral College, and both have options that describe it as a group of people appointed or elected by each state to formally elect the President and Vice President. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Most people have heard of the Electoral College during presidential election years. But what exactly is the Electoral College? Options: A. The number of votes is based on how much a state gives to a candidate's campaign, B. States were given a permanent number of votes at the time the electoral college was founded, C. Based on the census, which is conducted every ten years, D. The House of Representatives decides every 4 years
Correct Option: C

Question: If a candidate receives zero votes in 39 states, he/she can still be elected president if he/she gains the popular vote in 11 of 12 remaining states. Which state is not included in one of the 12 states that could win the presidency?
Options: A. California, B. New York, C. Ohio, D. Arizona
Correct Option: D

To understand how this process began and how it continues today, we can look at the Constitution of the United States: article two, section one, clause two of the constitution. It specifies how many electors each state is entitled to have. Since 1964, there have been 538 electors in each presidential election. How do they decide on the number 538? Well, the number of electors is equal to the total voting membership of the United States Congress. 435 representatives, plus 100 senators, and 3 electors from the District of Columbia. Essentially, the Democratic candidate and Republican candidate are each trying to add up the electors in every state so that they surpass 270 electoral votes, or just over half the 538 votes, and win the presidency. So how do states even get electoral votes? Each state receives a particular number of electors based on population size. The census is conducted every 10 years, so every time the census happens, states might gain or lose a few electoral votes. Let's say you're a voter in California, a state with 55 electoral votes. If your candidate wins in California, they get all 55 of the state's electoral votes. If your candidate loses, they get none. This is why many presidential candidates want to win states like Texas, Florida, and New York. If you currently add up the electoral votes of those three states, you would have 96 electoral votes. Even if a candidate won North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, Wyoming, Vermont, New Hampshire. Connecticut and West Virginia, they would only gain 31 electoral votes total from those eight states. Here is where it can get a little tricky. On a rare occasion, like in the year 2000, someone can win the popular vote but fail to gain 270 electoral votes. This means that the winner may have won and collected their electoral votes by small margins, winning just enough states with just enough electoral votes, but the losing candidate may have captured large voter margins in the remaining states. If this is the case, the very large margins secured by the losing candidate in the other states would add up to over 50% of the ballots cast nationally. Therefore, the losing candidate may have gained more than 50% of the ballots cast by voters, but failed to gain 270 of the electoral votes. Some critics of the electoral college argue the system gives an unfair advantage to states with large numbers of electoral votes. Think of it this way. It is possible for a candidate to not get a single person's vote -- not one vote -- in 39 states, or the District of Columbia, yet be elected president by winning the popular vote in just 11 of these 12 states: California, New York, Texas, Florida, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, New Jersey, North Carolina, Georgia or Virginia. This is why both parties pay attention to these states. However, others argue that the electoral college protects small states such as Rhode Island, Vermont and New Hampshire, and even geographically large states with small populations like Alaska, Wyoming and the Dakotas. That's because a candidate can't completely ignore small states, because in a close election, every electoral vote counts. There are certain states that have a long history of voting for a particular party. These are known as "safe states." For the past four election cycles -- in 1996, 2000, 2004 and 2008 -- Democrats could count on states like Oregon, Maryland, Michigan and Massachusetts, whereas the Republicans could count on states like Mississippi, Alabama, Kansas and Idaho. States that are teetering between between parties are called "swing states." In the past four election cycles, Ohio and Florida have been swing states, twice providing electoral votes for a Democratic candidate, and twice providing electoral votes for a Republican candidate. Think about it. Do you live in a safe state? If so, is it a Democratic or Republican safe state? Do you live in a swing state? Are your neighboring states swing or safe? Is the population in your state increasing or decreasing? And do not forget, when you are watching the electoral returns on election night every four years and the big map of the United States is on the screen, know that the magic number is 270 and start adding.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are safe states?
Options: A. States that are always won by the candidate that spends the most money to campaign, B. States that have a long history of voting for a particular party, C. States that vote for the incumbent, D. States that forfeit their electoral votes
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. The Electoral College is a group of people elected by each state to formally elect the President and Vice President of the United States., B. The Electoral College is a group of people appointed by the President to advise on legislation., C. The Electoral College is a system used to determine the winner of a presidential election., D. The Electoral College is a group of people elected by the people to represent their state in Congress. Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the total voting membership of the United States Congress., B. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the total population of the United States., C. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the number of states in the United States., D. The number of electors in the Electoral College is equal to the number of representatives in the House of Representatives. Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 55 electoral votes, they will receive 55 electoral votes from that state., B. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 10 electoral votes, they will receive 10 electoral votes from that state., C. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 5 electoral votes, they will receive 5 electoral votes from that state., D. If a candidate wins the popular vote in a state with 20 electoral votes, they will receive 20 electoral votes from that state. Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The Electoral College system gives an unfair advantage to states with large numbers of electoral votes., B. The Electoral College system gives an unfair advantage to states with small numbers of electoral votes., C. The Electoral College system is fair and gives equal representation to all states., D. The Electoral College system is biased towards urban areas. Correct Option: A
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 11 states, while losing the popular vote in the remaining 39 states., B. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in all 50 states., C. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 5 states., D. A candidate can win the presidency by winning the popular vote in just 2 states. Correct Option: A
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. The Electoral College system is a good way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., B. The Electoral College system is a bad way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., C. The Electoral College system is a neutral way to ensure that small states have a voice in the presidential election., D. The Electoral College system is not relevant to small states. Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly listed. However, based on the question intent, options, and content of the provided generated MCQs, none of them match the ground truth MCQ.

Question: What are safe states?
Options: A. States that are always won by the candidate that spends the most money to campaign, B. States that have a long history of voting for a particular party, C. States that vote for the incumbent, D. States that forfeit their electoral votes
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Take an adjective such as "implacable," or a verb like "proliferate," or even another noun, "crony," and add a suffix, such as "-ity," or "-tion," or "-ism." You've created a new noun. "Implacability," "proliferation," "cronyism." Sounds impressive, right? Wrong! You've just unleashed a flesh-eating zombie. Nouns made from other parts of speech are called nominalizations. Academics love them. So do lawyers, bureaucrats, business writers. I call them zombie nouns, because they consume the living. They cannibalize active verbs, they suck the lifeblood from adjectives, and they substitute abstract entities for human beings. Here's an example. "The proliferation of nominalizations in a discursive formation may be an indication of a tendency towards pomposity and abstraction." Huh? This sentence contains no fewer than seven nominalizations, yet it fails to tell us who is doing what. When we eliminate, or reanimate, most of the zombie nouns, so "tendency" becomes "tend," "abstraction" becomes "abstract," then we add a human subject and some active verbs, the sentence springs back to life. "Writers who overload their sentences with nominalizations tend to sound pompous and abstract." Only one zombie noun -- the key word "nominalizations" -- has been allowed to remain standing. At their best, nominalizations help us express complex ideas, perception, intelligence, epistemology. At their worst, they impede clear communication. To get a feeling for how zombie nouns work, release a few of them into a lively sentence and watch them sap all its energy. George Orwell played this game in his essay "Politics in the English Language." He started with a well-known verse from the book of Ecclesiastes in the Bible. It says "I returned and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all." Now here's Orwell's modern English version. "Objective considerations of contemporary phenomena compel the conclusion that success or failure in competitive activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity, but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be taken into account." The Bible passage speaks to our senses and emotions with concrete nouns, descriptions of people, and punchy, abstract nouns such as "race," "battle," "riches," "time," "chance." Not a zombie among them. Orwell's satirical translation, on the other hand, is teeming with nominalizations and other vague abstractions. The zombies have taken over, and the humans have fled the village. Zombie nouns do their worst damage when they gather in jargon-generating packs and swallow every noun, verb and adjective in sight. So "globe" becomes "global," becomes "globalize," becomes "globalization." The grandfather of all nominalizations, antidisestablishmentarianism, contains at least two verbs, three adjectives, and six other nouns inside its distended belly. A paragraph heavily populated by nominalizations will send your readers straight to sleep. Rescue them from the zombie apocalypse with vigorous verb-driven sentences that are concrete and clearly structured. You want your sentences to live, not to join the living dead.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Nominalizations are
Options: A. Nouns formed from other parts of speech, B. Meaningless jargon, C. Verbs formed from adjectives, D. Compound words, E. Adjectives formed from nouns
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term used to describe nouns created from other parts of speech, such as verbs or adjectives, by adding a suffix? Options: A. Nominalization, B. Zombie noun, C. Jargon, D. Abstraction Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary effect of using too many nominalizations in writing? Options: A. It enhances clear communication, B. It improves the structure of the sentence, C. It impedes clear communication, D. It has no impact on writing Correct Option: C
Question 3: How can using nominalizations in writing be compared to unleashing a "flesh-eating zombie"? Options: A. It brings the writing to life, B. It makes the writing more engaging, C. It consumes the living and sucks the lifeblood from other words, D. It has no effect on the writing Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of using nominalizations in writing, according to the transcript? Options: A. To make the writing more complex and abstract, B. To express complex ideas and perception, C. To confuse the reader, D. To make the writing more concise Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to George Orwell, what is the effect of using nominalizations in writing, as illustrated in his essay "Politics in the English Language"? Options: A. It enhances clear communication, B. It makes the writing more engaging, C. It impedes clear communication and makes the writing seem pompous and abstract, D. It has no impact on writing Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the term used to describe the process of taking a sentence with nominalizations and rewriting it to make it more concrete and engaging? Options: A. Nominalization, B. Zombie noun, C. Reanimation, D. Jargon Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can writers use nominalizations effectively, according to the transcript? Options: A. By using them to express complex ideas and perception, B. By using them to confuse the structure of the sentence, C. By using them to confuse the reader, D. By using them sparingly and only when necessary Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the result of using too many nominalizations in a paragraph, according to the transcript? Options: A. The paragraph becomes more engaging and interesting, B. The paragraph becomes more concrete and clearly structured, C. The paragraph sends the reader straight to sleep, D. The paragraph has no effect on the reader Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do nominalizations affect the tone and style of writing, according to the transcript? Options: A. They make the writing more formal and professional, B. They make the writing more engaging and conversational, C. They make the writing seem pompous and abstract, D. They have no impact on the tone and style of writing Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall message of the transcript regarding the use of nominalizations in writing? Options: A. Nominalizations are essential for clear and effective writing, B. Nominalizations are a necessary evil in writing, C. Nominalizations can be damaging to clear communication and should be used sparingly, D. Nominalizations have no impact on writing Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

It says "I returned and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all." Now here's Orwell's modern English version. "Objective considerations of contemporary phenomena compel the conclusion that success or failure in competitive activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity, but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be taken into account." The Bible passage speaks to our senses and emotions with concrete nouns, descriptions of people, and punchy, abstract nouns such as "race," "battle," "riches," "time," "chance." Not a zombie among them. Orwell's satirical translation, on the other hand, is teeming with nominalizations and other vague abstractions. The zombies have taken over, and the humans have fled the village. Zombie nouns do their worst damage when they gather in jargon-generating packs and swallow every noun, verb and adjective in sight. So "globe" becomes "global," becomes "globalize," becomes "globalization." The grandfather of all nominalizations, antidisestablishmentarianism, contains at least two verbs, three adjectives, and six other nouns inside its distended belly. A paragraph heavily populated by nominalizations will send your readers straight to sleep. Rescue them from the zombie apocalypse with vigorous verb-driven sentences that are concrete and clearly structured. You want your sentences to live, not to join the living dead.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Multisyllabic words such as globalization and epistemology
Options: A. Make you sound smarter than you really are, B. Energize dull sentences, C. Wake up the living dead, D. Must be avoided at all costs, E. Should be used with care
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:

It consumes the living and sucks the lifeblood from other words, D. It has no effect on the writing Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of using nominalizations in writing, according to the transcript? Options: A. To make the writing more complex and abstract, B. To express complex ideas and perception, C. To confuse the reader, D. To make the writing more concise Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to George Orwell, what is the effect of using nominalizations in writing, as illustrated in his essay "Politics in the English Language"? Options: A. Question 7: How can writers use nominalizations effectively, according to the transcript? Options: A. By using them to express complex ideas and perception, B. **Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Take an adjective such as "implacable," or a verb like "proliferate," or even another noun, "crony," and add a suffix, such as "-ity," or "-tion," or "-ism." You've created a new noun. "Implacability," "proliferation," "cronyism." Sounds impressive, right? Wrong! You've just unleashed a flesh-eating zombie. Nouns made from other parts of speech are called nominalizations. Academics love them. So do lawyers, bureaucrats, business writers. I call them zombie nouns, because they consume the living. They cannibalize active verbs, they suck the lifeblood from adjectives, and they substitute abstract entities for human beings. Here's an example. "The proliferation of nominalizations in a discursive formation may be an indication of a tendency towards pomposity and abstraction." Huh? This sentence contains no fewer than seven nominalizations, yet it fails to tell us who is doing what. When we eliminate, or reanimate, most of the zombie nouns, so "tendency" becomes "tend," "abstraction" becomes "abstract," then we add a human subject and some active verbs, the sentence springs back to life. "Writers who overload their sentences with nominalizations tend to sound pompous and abstract." Only one zombie noun -- the key word "nominalizations" -- has been allowed to remain standing. At their best, nominalizations help us express complex ideas, perception, intelligence, epistemology. At their worst, they impede clear communication. To get a feeling for how zombie nouns work, release a few of them into a lively sentence and watch them sap all its energy. George Orwell played this game in his essay "Politics in the English Language." He started with a well-known verse from the book of Ecclesiastes in the Bible. It says "I returned and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all." Now here's Orwell's modern English version. "Objective considerations of contemporary phenomena compel the conclusion that success or failure in competitive activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity, but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be taken into account." The Bible passage speaks to our senses and emotions with concrete nouns, descriptions of people, and punchy, abstract nouns such as "race," "battle," "riches," "time," "chance." Not a zombie among them. Orwell's satirical translation, on the other hand, is teeming with nominalizations and other vague abstractions. Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ is asking about the state of the cloned cell after it has been shocked. The correct answer is that it acts as a zygote.

Among the generated MCQs, the one that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. However, it only talks about waking up the new cell and doesn't explicitly state the cell's state after being shocked.

A closer match would be a question that asks about the state of the cell after the nucleus has been placed into the empty egg cell and shocked. Unfortunately, there isn't a generated MCQ that directly matches the ground truth MCQ.

However, based on the available options, I would say that Question 6 is the closest match, as it talks about the step after placing the nucleus into the empty egg cell, which is to wake up the new cell.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The first 10 amendments
to the U.S. Constitution -- also known as the Bill of Rights -- were ratified or passed
over 200 years ago. But even though they're a bit, well, old, these first 10 amendments are still
the most debated and discussed section of our Constitution today. So, can you remember what they are? Let's take a look. The First Amendment
is the freedom of speech, press, religion, assembly and petition. This may be the most revered
of the amendments. The First Amendment protects our rights
to say and write our opinions, worship how we please,
assemble together peacefully and petition our government,
if we feel the need. The Second Amendment
is the right to bear arms. The original intent
of the Second Amendment was to protect colonists
from the invading British soldiers, but it now guarantees
that you have the right to own a gun to defend
yourself and your property. The Third Amendment is called
the "Quartering" amendment. It was written in response
to the British occupation, and as a result of the colonists
having to house -- or quarter -- soldiers in their homes
during the American Revolution. Because of this amendment, our government can never force us
to house soldiers in our home. The Fourth Amendment
is the right to search and seizure. The police can't come into our home
without a search warrant and take our personal property. Today, many concerns have arisen
about our rights to privacy in technology. For example, can the government track
your location with your smartphone, or can social media postings
such as on Facebook and Twitter be used without a warrant? On to the Fifth:
It's all about due process. You've probably heard the phrase
"I plead the Fifth" in movies or on TV. They're talking about the Fifth Amendment, which says that you don't have to take
the witness stand against yourself if you may end up incriminating yourself. OK, we're halfway done. The Sixth and Seventh Amendments
are about how the legal system works. If you're accused of a crime, you have the right to a speedy
public trial and an impartial jury. You also have the right to a lawyer, and the right to take
the stand if you choose. This is important because it will prevent
the accused from sitting in prison forever and insists that the prosecution
proceed with undue delay. The Seventh says you have
the right to a jury trial, where 12 impartial peers decide
your innocence or guilt in the courtroom, as opposed to a judge doing it all alone. The Eight Amendment prohibits
cruel and unusual punishment. Is the death penalty cruel? Is it unusual? It's hard for Americans to agree
on the definitions of cruel and unusual. The Ninth and Tenth Amendments
are called the non-rights amendments. They say that the rights
not listed in the Bill of Rights are retained by the people in the states. We have other rights
that are not listed in the Constitution, and the states have the right
to make their own policies, like instituting state taxes. So now you know all 10 amendments. Can you remember them all? If not, remember this: the Bill of Rights is a crucial piece
of American history, and though society
has undergone many changes these past 200 and some years, the interpretation and application
of these amendments are as vital today as they were when they were written.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is another name for the Bill of Rights?
Options: A. The Constitution, B. The first ten amendments, C. The Preamble, D. The Articles of Confederation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of the First Amendment? Options: A. To protect the right to bear arms, B. To guarantee freedom of speech, press, religion, assembly, and petition, C. To ensure due process in the legal system, D. To prohibit cruel and unusual punishment Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main concern addressed by the Fourth Amendment? Options: A. The right to a speedy public trial, B. The right to search and seizure, C. The right to bear arms, D. The right to a jury trial Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the original intent of the Second Amendment? Options: A. To protect colonists from the invading British soldiers, B. To guarantee freedom of speech and press, C. To ensure due process in the legal system, D. To prohibit cruel and unusual punishment Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the significance of the phrase "I plead the Fifth" in the context of the Fifth Amendment? Options: A. It means that you have the right to a speedy public trial, B. It means that you have the right to search and seizure, C. It means that you don't have to take the witness stand against yourself if you may end up incriminating yourself, D. It means that you have the right to bear arms Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do the Ninth and Tenth Amendments relate to the Bill of Rights? Options: A. They list additional rights not included in the original Bill of Rights, B. They guarantee freedom of speech and press, C. They ensure due process in the legal system, D. They say that the rights not listed in the Bill of Rights are retained by the people in the states Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the main concern regarding the Fourth Amendment in today's society? Options: A. The right to a speedy public trial, B. The right to search and seizure, C. The right to bear arms, D. The right to a jury trial Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the Third Amendment relate to the British occupation of the American colonies? Options: A. It guarantees freedom of speech and press, B. It ensures due process in the legal system, C. It prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, D. It was written in response to the British occupation, and as a result of the colonists having to house soldiers in their homes during the American Revolution Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the significance of the Bill of Rights in American history? Options: A. It guarantees freedom of speech and press, B. It ensures due process in the legal system, C. It prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, D. It is a crucial piece of American history, and though society has undergone many changes these past 200 and some years, the interpretation and application of these amendments are as vital today as they were when they were written Correct Option: D
Question 9: How do the First and Second Amendments relate to each other? Options: A. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech and press, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, B. The First Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, while the Second Amendment guarantees freedom of speech and press, C. The First Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, D. The First Amendment guarantees the right to search and seizure, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to a jury trial Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main challenge in interpreting and applying the Eighth Amendment? Options: A. Defining what constitutes cruel and unusual punishment, B. Defining what constitutes freedom of speech and press, C. Defining what constitutes due process in the legal system, D. Defining what constitutes the right to bear arms Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about another name for the Bill of Rights. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 8 does mention the significance of the Bill of Rights in American history.

However, a more relevant question that at least mentions the Bill of Rights is not available. But among the available options, Question 8 has some connection to the Bill of Rights.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ would be: 8

However the one that is most similar in intent to the ground truth question is:

**Generated Question 1 does not speak to the Sixth and Seventh Amendments but Generated Question 4 does speak to part of the content of the Sixth Amendment**

However the one that is most similar in intent to the ground truth question is:

**Generated Question 2 does speak to the content of the Fourth Amendment but Generated Question 6 does speak to the content of the Fourth Amendment and the idea of modern concerns, however neither of these questions speak to the Sixth and Seventh Amendments**

However the one that is most similar in intent to the ground truth question is:

Since none of the questions directly match the ground truth question the best course of action is to choose the question that is most similar in content.

**Generated Question 4 does speak to part of the content of the Sixth Amendment and is the closest match**

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **4**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The first 10 amendments
to the U.S. Constitution -- also known as the Bill of Rights -- were ratified or passed
over 200 years ago. But even though they're a bit, well, old, these first 10 amendments are still
the most debated and discussed section of our Constitution today. So, can you remember what they are? Let's take a look. The First Amendment
is the freedom of speech, press, religion, assembly and petition. This may be the most revered
of the amendments. The First Amendment protects our rights
to say and write our opinions, worship how we please,
assemble together peacefully and petition our government,
if we feel the need. The Second Amendment
is the right to bear arms. The original intent
of the Second Amendment was to protect colonists
from the invading British soldiers, but it now guarantees
that you have the right to own a gun to defend
yourself and your property. The Third Amendment is called
the "Quartering" amendment. It was written in response
to the British occupation, and as a result of the colonists
having to house -- or quarter -- soldiers in their homes
during the American Revolution. Because of this amendment, our government can never force us
to house soldiers in our home. The Fourth Amendment
is the right to search and seizure. The police can't come into our home
without a search warrant and take our personal property. Today, many concerns have arisen
about our rights to privacy in technology. For example, can the government track
your location with your smartphone, or can social media postings
such as on Facebook and Twitter be used without a warrant? On to the Fifth:
It's all about due process. You've probably heard the phrase
"I plead the Fifth" in movies or on TV. They're talking about the Fifth Amendment, which says that you don't have to take
the witness stand against yourself if you may end up incriminating yourself. OK, we're halfway done. The Sixth and Seventh Amendments
are about how the legal system works. If you're accused of a crime, you have the right to a speedy
public trial and an impartial jury. You also have the right to a lawyer, and the right to take
the stand if you choose. This is important because it will prevent
the accused from sitting in prison forever and insists that the prosecution
proceed with undue delay. The Seventh says you have
the right to a jury trial, where 12 impartial peers decide
your innocence or guilt in the courtroom, as opposed to a judge doing it all alone. The Eight Amendment prohibits
cruel and unusual punishment. Is the death penalty cruel? Is it unusual? It's hard for Americans to agree
on the definitions of cruel and unusual. The Ninth and Tenth Amendments
are called the non-rights amendments. They say that the rights
not listed in the Bill of Rights are retained by the people in the states. We have other rights
that are not listed in the Constitution, and the states have the right
to make their own policies, like instituting state taxes. So now you know all 10 amendments. Can you remember them all? If not, remember this: the Bill of Rights is a crucial piece
of American history, and though society
has undergone many changes these past 200 and some years, the interpretation and application
of these amendments are as vital today as they were when they were written.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When were the Bill of Rights written?
Options: A. 1720, B. 1677, C. 1789, D. 1985
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of the First Amendment? Options: A. To protect the right to bear arms, B. To guarantee freedom of speech, press, religion, assembly, and petition, C. To ensure due process in the legal system, D. To prohibit cruel and unusual punishment Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the main concern addressed by the Fourth Amendment? Options: A. The right to a speedy public trial, B. The right to search and seizure, C. The right to bear arms, D. The right to a jury trial Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the original intent of the Second Amendment? Options: A. To protect colonists from the invading British soldiers, B. To guarantee freedom of speech and press, C. To ensure due process in the legal system, D. To prohibit cruel and unusual punishment Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the significance of the phrase "I plead the Fifth" in the context of the Fifth Amendment? Options: A. It means that you have the right to a speedy public trial, B. It means that you have the right to search and seizure, C. It means that you don't have to take the witness stand against yourself if you may end up incriminating yourself, D. It means that you have the right to bear arms Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do the Ninth and Tenth Amendments relate to the Bill of Rights? Options: A. They list additional rights not included in the original Bill of Rights, B. They guarantee freedom of speech and press, C. They ensure due process in the legal system, D. They say that the rights not listed in the Bill of Rights are retained by the people in the states Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the main concern regarding the Fourth Amendment in today's society? Options: A. The right to a speedy public trial, B. The right to search and seizure, C. The right to bear arms, D. The right to a jury trial Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the Third Amendment relate to the British occupation of the American colonies? Options: A. It guarantees freedom of speech and press, B. It ensures due process in the legal system, C. It prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, D. It was written in response to the British occupation, and as a result of the colonists having to house soldiers in their homes during the American Revolution Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the significance of the Bill of Rights in American history? Options: A. It guarantees freedom of speech and press, B. It ensures due process in the legal system, C. It prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, D. It is a crucial piece of American history, and though society has undergone many changes these past 200 and some years, the interpretation and application of these amendments are as vital today as they were when they were written Correct Option: D
Question 9: How do the First and Second Amendments relate to each other? Options: A. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech and press, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, B. The First Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, while the Second Amendment guarantees freedom of speech and press, C. The First Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to bear arms, D. The First Amendment guarantees the right to search and seizure, while the Second Amendment guarantees the right to a jury trial Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main challenge in interpreting and applying the Eighth Amendment? Options: A. Defining what constitutes cruel and unusual punishment, B. Defining what constitutes freedom of speech and press, C. Defining what constitutes due process in the legal system, D. Defining what constitutes the right to bear arms Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Translator: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar It's March the 17th in A.D. 73. We're visiting ancient Rome
to watch the Liberalia, an annual festival that celebrates
the liberty of Rome's citizens. We're looking in at a 17-year-old
named Lucius Popidius Secundus. He's not from a poor family, but he lives
in the region known as the Subura, a poorer neighborhood in Rome,
yet close to the center of the city. (Gong) The tenants of these
apartments are crammed in, (Grunting) which poses considerable risk. Fires are frequent and the smell of ash
and smoke in the morning is not uncommon. Lucius, who awoke at dawn,
has family duties to perform today. (Cheering) His 15-year-old brother is coming of age. Half the children in ancient Rome
die before they reach adulthood, so this is a particularly
important milestone. Lucius watches his brother
stand in his new toga before the household shrine
with its protective deities, as he places his bulla,
a protective amulet, in the shrine with a prayer of thanks. The bulla had worked.
It had protected him. Unlike many others,
he had survived to become an adult. At 17, Lucius has almost
completed his education. He has learned to speak well,
make public speeches, and how to read and write
both Latin and Greek. His father has taught him
the types of things you can't learn in the classroom: how to run, how to swim, and how to fight. Lucius could choose, at 17,
to become a military tribune and command soldiers
on the edge of the Empire. But in other ways,
Lucius is still a child. He's not trusted
to arrange business deals. His father will take care
of that until he is 25. And Dad will arrange Lucius' marriage
to a girl 10 years younger. His dad has his eye on a family
with a 7-year-old daughter. Back to the Liberalia. As Lucius leaves with his family, the shops are open as the population
goes about its business. The streets are full
of itinerant traders selling trinkets and people bustling from place to place. Large wagons are not allowed
in the city until after the ninth hour but the streets are still crowded. Fathers and uncles
take the kids to the Forum Augustus to see statues of Rome's famous warriors like Aeneas, who led Rome's ancestors,
the Trojans, to Italy. And Romulus, Rome's founder. And all the great generals of the Republic
from more than 100 years earlier. Lovingly, we can imagine
fathers and guardians with their now adult children remembering stories of Rome's glory and re-telling the good deeds and sayings
of the great men of the past: lessons on how to live well, and to overcome the follies of youth. There is a sense of history in this place,
relevant to their present. Romans made an empire
without end in time and space. (Thump) Rome was destined to be
eternal through warfare. Wars were a fact of life, even in A.D. 73. There are campaigns in the north
of England and into Scotland, to the north of the River
Danube into Romania, and on the frontier
between Syria and Iraq to the east. It's now the eighth hour --
time to head for the baths. Lucius and his family head up
the Via Lata, the wide street, to the Campus Martius,
and the enormous Baths of Agrippa. The family members leave
the clients and freedmen outside, and enter the baths with their peer group. Baths would change from dark,
steamy rooms to light ones. The Romans had perfected window glass. Everyone moves from the cold room to the tepid room and to the very hot room. (Man) Oops! More than an hour later, the bathers leave massaged, oiled, (Whistling) and have been scraped down with a strigil to remove the remaining dirt. At the ninth hour, seven hours
after they left home, the men return for a celebratory dinner. Dinner is an intimate affair, with nine people
reclining around the low table. Slaves attend to their every need if the diners, through gestures,
demand more food and wine. As the day closes, we can hear
the rumble of wagons outside. The clients and freedmen, with a meal of robust
-- if inferior -- food inside them, shuffle off to the now tepid baths before returning
to their apartment blocks. Back at Lucius' house,
the drinking continues into the night. Lucius and his stepbrother
don't look too well. A slave stands by in case
either of them needs to vomit. With hindsight, we know Lucius' future. In 20 years' time, the Emperor Vespasian's
youngest son, Domitian, as emperor, will enact a reign of terror. Will Lucius survive? (Drums)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was a common smell in early Roman mornings in AD 79?
Options: A. Bacon and eggs, B. Ash and smoke, C. Human waste, D. Cattle moving from the west
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the festival that Lucius and his family are attending in ancient Rome? Options: A. Liberalia, B. Roman Games, C. Festival of the Gods, D. Festival of the Empire Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the significance of Lucius' brother reaching the age of 15 in ancient Rome? Options: A. It marks the beginning of adulthood, B. It marks the end of childhood, C. It marks the beginning of education, D. It marks the beginning of military service Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the name of the protective amulet that Lucius' brother places in the household shrine? Options: A. Bulla, B. Amulet of Rome, C. Protective Charm, D. Good Luck Token Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the baths that Lucius and his family visit in the afternoon? Options: A. Baths of Agrippa, B. Roman Baths, C. Public Baths, D. Private Baths Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the significance of the ninth hour in ancient Rome? Options: A. It marks the beginning of the day, B. It marks the end of the day, C. It marks the time when large wagons are allowed in the city, D. It marks the time when the men return for a celebratory dinner Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the name of the Emperor who will enact a reign of terror in 20 years' time? Options: A. Emperor Vespasian, B. Emperor Domitian, C. Emperor Augustus, D. Emperor Trajan Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of the strigil used in the baths? Options: A. To massage the skin, B. To oil the skin, C. To scrape down the remaining dirt, D. To clean the skin Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the family members leaving the clients and freedmen outside when entering the baths? Options: A. It marks the beginning of the bathing process, B. It marks the end of the bathing process, C. It marks the time when the family members are allowed to enter the baths, D. It is a social distinction between the family members and the clients and freedmen Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the name of the street that Lucius and his family walk on to get to the baths? Options: A. Via Lata, B. Roman Street, C. Public Street, D. Private Street Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the purpose of the diners use gestures to demand more food and wine during the celebratory dinner? Options: A. To show appreciation for the food and wine, B. To show gratitude to the slaves, C. To demand more food and wine, D. To signal the end of the meal Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

the drinking continues into the night. Lucius and his stepbrother
don't look too well. A slave stands by in case
either of them needs to vomit. With hindsight, we know Lucius' future. In 20 years' time, the Emperor Vespasian's
youngest son, Domitian, as emperor, will enact a reign of terror. Will Lucius survive? (Drums)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Although he can join the military at 17, what is Lucius not trusted to do until he is 25 years old?
Options: A. Wear a toga, B. Swim in the ocean, C. Give public speeches, D. Conduct business transactions

Question 1: What is the name of the festival that Lucius and his family are attending in ancient Rome? Options: A. Liberalia, B. Roman Games, C. Festival of the Gods, D. Festival of the Empire Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Translator: tom carter
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar It's March the 17th in A.D. 73. We're visiting ancient Rome
to watch the Liberalia, an annual festival that celebrates
the liberty of Rome's citizens. We're looking in at a 17-year-old
named Lucius Popidius Secundus. He's not from a poor family, but he lives
in the region known as the Subura, a poorer neighborhood in Rome,
yet close to the center of the city. (Gong) The tenants of these
apartments are crammed in, (Grunting) which poses considerable risk. Fires are frequent and the smell of ash
and smoke in the morning is not uncommon. Lucius, who awoke at dawn,
has family duties to perform today. (Cheering) His 15-year-old brother is coming of age. Half the children in ancient Rome
die before they reach adulthood, so this is a particularly
important milestone. Lucius watches his brother
stand in his new toga before the household shrine
with its protective deities, as he places his bulla,
a protective amulet, in the shrine with a prayer of thanks. The bulla had worked.
It had protected him. Unlike many others,
he had survived to become an adult. At 17, Lucius has almost
completed his education. He has learned to speak well,
make public speeches, and how to read and write
both Latin and Greek. His father has taught him
the types of things you can't learn in the classroom: how to run, how to swim, and how to fight. Lucius could choose, at 17,
to become a military tribune and command soldiers
on the edge of the Empire. But in other ways,
Lucius is still a child. He's not trusted
to arrange business deals. His father will take care
of that until he is 25. And Dad will arrange Lucius' marriage
to a girl 10 years younger. His dad has his eye on a family
with a 7-year-old daughter. Back to the Liberalia. As Lucius leaves with his family, the shops are open as the population
goes about its business. The streets are full
of itinerant traders selling trinkets and people bustling from place to place. Large wagons are not allowed
in the city until after the ninth hour but the streets are still crowded. Fathers and uncles
take the kids to the Forum Augustus to see statues of Rome's famous warriors like Aeneas, who led Rome's ancestors,
the Trojans, to Italy. And Romulus, Rome's founder. And all the great generals of the Republic
from more than 100 years earlier. Lovingly, we can imagine
fathers and guardians with their now adult children remembering stories of Rome's glory and re-telling the good deeds and sayings
of the great men of the past: lessons on how to live well, and to overcome the follies of youth. There is a sense of history in this place,
relevant to their present. Romans made an empire
without end in time and space. (Thump) Rome was destined to be
eternal through warfare. Wars were a fact of life, even in A.D. 73. There are campaigns in the north
of England and into Scotland, to the north of the River
Danube into Romania, and on the frontier
between Syria and Iraq to the east. It's now the eighth hour --
time to head for the baths. Lucius and his family head up
the Via Lata, the wide street, to the Campus Martius,
and the enormous Baths of Agrippa. The family members leave
the clients and freedmen outside, and enter the baths with their peer group. Baths would change from dark,
steamy rooms to light ones. The Romans had perfected window glass. Everyone moves from the cold room to the tepid room and to the very hot room. (Man) Oops! More than an hour later, the bathers leave massaged, oiled, (Whistling) and have been scraped down with a strigil to remove the remaining dirt. At the ninth hour, seven hours
after they left home, the men return for a celebratory dinner. Dinner is an intimate affair, with nine people
reclining around the low table. Slaves attend to their every need if the diners, through gestures,
demand more food and wine. As the day closes, we can hear
the rumble of wagons outside. The clients and freedmen, with a meal of robust
-- if inferior -- food inside them, shuffle off to the now tepid baths before returning
to their apartment blocks. Back at Lucius' house,
the drinking continues into the night. Lucius and his stepbrother
don't look too well. A slave stands by in case
either of them needs to vomit. With hindsight, we know Lucius' future. In 20 years' time, the Emperor Vespasian's
youngest son, Domitian, as emperor, will enact a reign of terror. Will Lucius survive? (Drums)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At the baths, bathers participate in a more-than-an-hour long event that includes all of the following except:
Options: A. Baths in 3 different temperatures, B. A body massage and an oiling, C. A session of intense calisthenics, D. Their bodies are scraped with a strigil
Correct Option: C

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar It's March the 17th in A.D. 73. We're visiting ancient Rome
to watch the Liberalia, an annual festival that celebrates
the liberty of Rome's citizens. We're looking in at a 17-year-old
named Lucius Popidius Secundus. He's not from a poor family, but he lives
in the region known as the Subura, a poorer neighborhood in Rome,

and smoke in the morning is not uncommon. Lucius, who awoke at dawn,
has family duties to perform today. (Cheering) His 15-year-old brother is coming of age. Half the children in ancient Rome
die before they reach adulthood, so this is a particularly
important milestone. Lucius watches his brother
stand in his new toga before the household shrine
with its protective deities, as he places his bulla,
a protective amulet, in the shrine with a prayer of thanks. The bulla had worked.
It had protected him. Unlike many others,
he had survived to become an adult. At 17, Lucius has almost
completed his education. He has learned to speak well,
make public speeches, and how to read and write
both Latin and Greek. His father has taught him

goes about its business. The streets are full

in the city until after the ninth hour but the streets are still crowded. Fathers and uncles

the Trojans, to Italy. And Romulus, Rome's founder. And all the great generals of the Republic
from more than 100 years earlier. Lovingly, we can imagine

relevant to their present. Romans made an empire
without end in time and space. (Thump) Rome was destined to be

of England and into Scotland, to the north of the River

youngest son, Domitian, as emperor, will enact a reign of terror. Will Lucius survive? (Drums)
